posts.name: Hale Barber
posts.cooked:
Hello all! This is Hale Barber, the assistant captain of team 3243, the AMES Amperes, and a huge software nerd.

Over the last year and a half, I’ve been working on a custom testing framework for my team, to help improve our code reliability. It’s been a long time in the making, and all the files have been public on github for that whole time, but it’s finally to a state I’m finally happy with, and I want to properly share it with the community.

The Ammeter Live Tester is a piece of software you can include in your robot code to create and run automatic integration and end-to-end tests. The tests run in the context of the robot, so tests can run motors, and test interactions between subsystems. It includes powerful utilities to make writing test as easy as possible.

The live tester sends information to a program running on the driver station (the Ammeter client) so that the user can see the results, and manage the testing in other ways. The user can choose what groups of tests are run, answer questions asked by tests, and see the results of the tests.

image 775×734 18.1 KB

image 775×734 18.1 KB

image 775×734 18.1 KB

The code for Ammeter, along with binaries where applicable, is available on github (links are at the bottom). Those github pages also have extensive READMEs, as well as a link to a full usage guide.

I hope that Ammeter can become a proper part of the FIRST community, and to that end I’ve done my best to put everything in place to make it a proper open source project. Automatic testing is omnipresent in the software industry, and I would love to see its benefits and practices spread to FRC . I’ll be reviewing pull requests and github issues, so if your team makes an improvement to the framework, or finds a problem, put it on github! Let’s build better robots together!

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Cool! But what differences does this provide a team than what is already available out of the box in junit . Our typical workflow is we do all our unit testing using junit and it just runs when it builds and provides a report : image 1958×732 46.8 KB

image 1958×732 46.8 KB

image 1958×732 46.8 KB

We’ll write our tests in “test/java/frc” which is located from the root of the src folder in a project. Every time we build its automatically built ( or you can right click and select “run robot tests”.  If i’m not mistaken you’ve recreated the wheel. Where you looking to enable teams to use real practices for testing and didn’t know this was available , or did you see something that was lacking in Junit for FRC . Or maybe this is available for all programming languages?  What am I missing?

posts.name: Hale Barber
posts.cooked:
We also use JUnit, but Ammeter and JUnit provide fundamentally different types of tests. As I understand it, JUnit can’t run motors on the robot, or anything like that. Each class being unit tested is tested in isolation, so interactions between them can’t be tested.

JUnit is a unit testing framework, whereas Ammeter is a integration and end to end testing framework. So, for example, JUnit is what we use for testing our custom splines and path planning, but we use Ammeter to verify that motors, encoders, and PID positioning are functional.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
I understand now. This is not another implementation of automated unit tests but more of holistic testing platform.

As i am now interpreting this the differentiation is that unit testing would validate basic functionality and this platform would handle more complex real world testing.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: How does this differ from using the Mockito framework? I’ve been mocking hardware and running unit tests to validate mechanism behavior for a while.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
hydrogenh1:

JUnit can’t run motors on the robot

It can. WPILib used to automatically run the JUnit tests at allwpilib/wpilibjIntegrationTests at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub on a test board in Brad Miller’s office with various motors and sensors attached. That board has been disassembled for a while though.

posts.name: Hale Barber
posts.cooked: Ammeter differs from Mockito in that it doesn’t just create mocks, it runs on the actual robot, so you can verify physical structure and mechanics. For example, a well made test could figure out if the conversion ratio in code is different than the gearbox on the robot.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I was 99.99% sure this was the case and had done it in the past. Did not want to speak with any certainty.

posts.name: Hale Barber
posts.cooked: Ah, I never realized that! Does it just run them as soon as it’s deployed like with regular JUnit tests? Or is there a command I missed to run them during execution? A big thing I focused on with Ammeter is making it easy to run tests over the course of multiple cycles, is there a way to do that in JUnit? I’ve only really seen methods that run once, within a cycle.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
hydrogenh1:

Does it just run them as soon as it’s deployed like with regular JUnit tests?

Yes. WPILib’s setup statically constructed a mock DS to enable the robot program. C++'s Google Test is more flexible.
